Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project - SFS CB: Establishing the New Mexico Digital Forensics Academy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Upon award of a proposal, the Abstract is available in the Award Search application and via FastLane.
This project is establishing a permanent digital forensics program at Western New Mexico University (WNMU) in collaboration with Auburn University. It is providing a statewide digital forensics resource that currently does not exist in New Mexico. WNMU?s unique combined mission of regional community college as well as regional university provides unique opportunities to explore program integration with New Mexico 2-year law enforcement programs. Deliverables from this project include:

1. Establish an 18-hour minor in digital forensics as part of the WNMU undergraduate and graduate Criminal Justice programs.
2. Establish an 18-hour graduate certificate program in digital forensics as part of the WNMU Criminal Justice program.
3. Establish an advanced digital forensics training program for New Mexico law enforcement.
4. Conduct Regional workshops for diverse audiences drawn from New Mexico state and local law enforcement agencies as well as students from other campuses.

The intellectual challenge for this project is to determine how a small university in a remote corner of a large state can develop, deliver and sustain a technically challenging digital forensics program across a large state. The project is assessing courses learning outcomes as well as elements such as the practicality of course contents, the way the contents is delivered, the lab environment and setup, the effectiveness of projects and assignments, lab assistance quality and inclusion/exclusion suggestions for course contents and projects.

This first of its kind program in New Mexico enjoys broad support from the state government. This ensures a broad impact across the state. This program could serve as a model for other underserved states, particularly large, rural states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was to establish a "Digital Forensics Academy" at Western New Mexico University through the following objectives:

1. Establish an 18-hour minor in digital forensics as part of the WNMU undergraduate Criminal Justice program to be made available in a fully on-line format.
2. Establish an 18-hour graduate certificate program in digital forensics as part of the WNMU Criminal Justice program to be made available in a fully on-line format.
3. Establish an advanced digital forensics training program for New Mexico law enforcement.
4. Design an online, outreach version of the digital forensics program so that local, state and Federal law enforcement organizations can utilize the WNMU digital forensics program regardless of geographical location.
5. Leverage WNMU’s unique roles as both a community college and a regional university with graduate programs to develop a program to transition two-year college graduates into an upper division digital forensics program.
6. Continue Auburn’s already successful minority recruitment for SFS scholarships through Auburn’s digital forensic engagement with WNMU.
7. Support faculty development in digital forensics at WNMU and Auburn through joint workshops, joint teaching and joint publications.
8. Assist WNMU progressing through the NSA/DHS National Center of Academic Excellence qualification process.

Most, but not all of the objectives were achieved.

1, 2, 4. During the first year of the grant, the undergraduate minor and graduate certificate were created using a combination of existing and newly created courses. Both programs consist of four required courses and two elective courses. The two programs went through the institutional approval process during the second year and the state approval process during the third year, Both prgrams are offered in a fully on-line format. During the last year of the grant, there was a total headcount enrollment of 22 in  the four required undergraduate courses and 30 in the four required graduate courses.

3. Training was provided duriing the first three years of the grant to a variety of Federal, state, and local law enforcement personnel. The grant purchased twenty laptops during the first year to provide a mobile computer lab. Two training programs, one eight hour and one forty hour were provided that year to a total of 63 individuals. Two forty hour training programs were provided during the second year to a total of 21 individuals. One forty hour program was provided during the third year with 41 attendees. All of the programs were approved by the New Mexico Department of Public Safety for law enforcement CEU's by New Mexico certified police officers. The laptops are currently utilized for training in the WNMU Police Academy basic academy program.

5. A change in the scope of work was submitted in light if the university's elimination of the computer networking associates degree. The university committed to develop and deliver a new cyber security certification course to be added as an elective to the already developed WNMU Digital Forensics programs.  A course was developed, entitled "CISSP Exam Preparation" which was offered at the undergraduate and graduate levels during the summer 2017 Session. 12 graduate and 1 undergraduate students enrolled.  WNMU attempted to use the new certification-based 3 credit hour-course to reach out to students stranded by the closure of proprietary schools in New Mexico by e-mailing the staff assigned to assist such students at the New Mexico Higher Education Department multiple times. The plan was that the course would serve as a bridge to help these stranded students finish degrees in the WNMU digital forensics programs. However, staff turnover at HED resulted in our request for assistance in contacting stranded students not receiving a reply from HED until June 19, three months after our initial e-mail was sent. By then, the course had already begun so it was too late as the course had begun on May 31.

6. The objective of supporting minority recruitment into the SFS program at Auburn was not achieved. The principal investigator for the coordinating institution took a position at Mississippi State during the first year of the grant.

7.8. Neither of the last two objectives were achieved, primarily due to state-wide cuts to higher education budgets in New Mexico. The original grant proposal assumed the addition of a faculty line for the digital forensics program. That was never accomplised resulting in the coursework being delivered by a mix of adjunct and existing faculty at WNMU.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2017
Modified by: Curtis Hayes
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This grant was to establish a "Digital Forensics Academy" at Western New Mexico University through the following objectives: 1. Establish an 18-hour minor in digital forensics as part of the WNMU undergraduate Criminal Justice program to be made available in a fully on-line format. 2. Establish an 18-hour graduate certificate program in digital forensics as part of the WNMU Criminal Justice program to be made available in a fully on-line format. 3. Establish an advanced digital forensics training program for New Mexico law enforcement. 4. Design an online, outreach version of the digital forensics program so that local, state and Federal law enforcement organizations can utilize the WNMU digital forensics program regardless of geographical location. 5. Leverage WNMU?s unique roles as both a community college and a regional university with graduate programs to develop a program to transition two-year college graduates into an upper division digital forensics program. 6. Continue Auburn?s already successful minority recruitment for SFS scholarships through Auburn?s digital forensic engagement with WNMU. 7. Support faculty development in digital forensics at WNMU and Auburn through joint workshops, joint teaching and joint publications. 8. Assist WNMU progressing through the NSA/DHS National Center of Academic Excellence qualification process. Most, but not all of the objectives were achieved. 1, 2, 4. During the first year of the grant, the undergraduate minor and graduate certificate were created using a combination of existing and newly created courses. Both programs consist of four required courses and two elective courses. The two programs went through the institutional approval process during the second year and the state approval process during the third year, Both prgrams are offered in a fully on-line format. During the last year of the grant, there was a total headcount enrollment of 22 in the four required undergraduate courses and 30 in the four required graduate courses. 3. The grant purchased twenty laptops during the first year to provide a mobile computer lab. Two training programs, one eight hour and one forty hour were provided that year to a total of 63 individuals. Two forty hour training programs were provided during the second year to a total of 21 individuals. One forty hour program was provided during the third year with 41 attendees. All of the programs were approved by the New Mexico Department of Public Safety for law enforcement CEU's by New Mexico certified police officers. The laptops are currently utilized for training in the WNMU Police Academy basic academy program. 5. A change in the scope of work was submitted in light if the university's elimination of the computer networking associates degree. The university committed to develop and deliver a new cyber security certification course to be added as an elective to the already developed WNMU Digital Forensics programs. A course was developed, entitled "CISSP Exam Preparation" which was offered at the undergraduate and graduate levels during the summer 2017 Session. 12 graduate and 1 undergraduate students enrolled. WNMU attempted to use the new certification-based 3 credit hour-course to reach out to students stranded by the closure of proprietary schools in New Mexico by e-mailing the staff assigned to assist such students at the New Mexico Higher Education Department multiple times. The plan was that the course would serve as a bridge to help these stranded students finish degrees in the WNMU digital forensics programs. By then, the course had already begun so it was too late as the course had begun on May 31. 6. The objective of supporting minority recruitment into the SFS program at Auburn was not achieved. The principal investigator for the coordinating institution took a position at Mississippi State during the first year of the grant. 7.8. Neither of the last two objectives were achieved, primarily due to state-wide cuts to higher education budgets in New Mexico. The original grant proposal assumed the addition of a faculty line for the digital forensics program.
